items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate has risen to 3.7 per cent for July, up from 3.5 per cent in June, with 36,000 more people unemployed, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics data.

title.children: More Australians out of work, economy sheds 14,600 jobs in July

title.children: Young horse float driver for Ben Yole charged over crash that injured passengers, killed horses

items.synopsis: A private hydro scheme in Tasmania's north-west is capable of powering 800 homes — but questions are being asked about the impact on neighbouring properties.

title.children: 'It's totally wrong': Trees are dying on Donald's property as pastures turn to bogs

image.altText: An England player and a Matildas opponent challenge for the ball during the Women's World Cup semifinal.

items.synopsis: The Matildas' 3-1 loss to England creates history by becoming the most-watched TV program since the current audience measurement system began in 2001.

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal sets TV audience record

image.altText: Australia's football superstar Sam Kerr looks sad but gives a thumbs up to the crowd after the Matildas Women's World Cup loss.

image.altText: A man in a mask sitting on a chair.

title.children: 'Friends, it has just started': A hacker in hiding has a message for the world

image.altText: People walk across a street.

items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 3.7 per cent in July, surpassing most economists expectations. It comes as the local sharemarket is trading lower despite a flurry of earnings reports from some of Australia's biggest companies. Follow live.

title.children: Future rate rises 'hard to justify' as unemployment hits 3.7pc, Telstra and Origin profits surge, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket is down sharply for a second straight day, as concerns grow about China's economy and Wall Street's negative sentiment about US interest rates gains traction amongst investors. As we approach 1:30pm AEST, the ASX is down 0.8% to 7,137 points. Locally, only the academic services and utilities sectors are in positive territory — although the gains for both are incredibly slim. Healthcare and industrials have shed 1.5% each, while financials is down 1.3%. Combined with an Aussie dollar staying below 64 US cents on the back of the unemployment data, the ASX is down nearly to 3% compared to where it finished up last Friday. The top movers so far are: Inghams +14.4% IPH +9.7% Orora +8.4% Abacus Storage King +4.3% Super Retail Group +4.1% As for the bottom movers: Core Lithium -23.4% Lake Resources -7.5% Domain Holdings -7.1% Polynovo -6.8% NRW Holdings -6.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX down sharply as majority of sectors dragged into the red

children.content: down sharply for a second straight day
, as concerns grow about China's economy and Wall Street's negative sentiment about US interest rates gains traction amongst investors.
Locally, only the academic services and utilities sectors are in positive territory — although the gains for both are incredibly slim.
Healthcare and industrials have shed 1.5% each, while financials is down 1.3%.
Aussie dollar staying below 64 US cents
on the back of the unemployment data, the ASX is down nearly to 3% compared to where it finished up last Friday.
The top movers so far are:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is already having a rough one this week, but it fell by nearly 1% after the ABS released the latest employment data. In the minutes after the employment data was released, the Australian dollar hit a low of 63.65 US cents, down by 0.9%. It also took its trans-Tasman cousin along for the ride too, dragging the New Zealand dollar down by 0.5% to 59.03 US cents. It's the lowest level the Aussie and NZ dollar have hit since November. "Cracks are finally appearing in the employment data, and that should clear up any doubt over whether the (Reserve Bank of Australia) is done hiking ," said Matt Simpson, senior market analyst at City Index. " They're done at 4.1% as far as I'm concerned now, with persistently weak data from China and easing from the (People's Bank of China) adding to the case of a peak rate."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian dollar tumbles after jobless rate surpasses expectations

children.content: The Aussie dollar is already having a rough one this week, but it
after the ABS released the latest employment data.
In the minutes after the employment data was released
, the Australian dollar hit a low of 63.65 US cents
It also took its trans-Tasman cousin along for the ride too, dragging the New Zealand dollar down by 0.5% to 59.03 US cents.
lowest level the Aussie and NZ dollar have hit since November
"Cracks are finally appearing in the employment data, and that
should clear up any doubt over whether the (Reserve Bank of Australia) is done hiking
," said Matt Simpson, senior market analyst at City Index.
They're done at 4.1% as far as I'm concerned now
, with persistently weak data from China and easing from the (People's Bank of China) adding to the case of a peak rate."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to deputy chief economist at AMP, Diana Mousina, who believes the most likely path forward now for the RBA is to keep rates on hold at 4.1%, before cutting sometime next year. Here's what she told business reporter Sue Lannin on the ABC News Channel a short time ago: "The RBA has been on hold for two months now and unless we see a break-out in wages or unless we see significant strength in the jobs market, which today's data suggests we're not, it is hard to justify another rate rise if we have already had two pauses ," she said. "I think rates will be on hold. "There is a risk of another rate rise from here, but I would say that the most likely path is that the cash rate will remain at 4.1% until we get some cuts next year. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economist says another interest rate rise would be 'hard to justify' now

children.content: deputy chief economist at AMP, Diana Mousina

it is hard to justify another rate rise if we have already had two pauses

the most likely path is that the cash rate will remain at 4.1% until we get some cuts next year.
